importantArticles.headline: Shares of Alibaba (NYSE: BABA) are tumbling on Friday.  The decline comes as the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell sharply.  As the fallout from President Donald Trump's tariffs continues to pummel markets, his latest executive order directly targets a key advantage of Chinese e-commerce platforms like Alibaba.

importantArticles.headline: As part of today's Market Minute, Madison Mills outlines the top stories of the trading day. Intel (INTC) stock plunges as US–China trade war tensions intensify. Dell Technologies (DELL) stock extends losses as Morgan Stanley (MS) analysts raise concerns about tariff impacts. Chinese tech stocks, like Alibaba (BABA), PDD Holdings (PDD), and JD.com (JD), tumble as China retaliates against Trump's new tariffs. Stay up to date on the latest market action, minute-by-minute, with Yahoo Finance's Market Minute.

importantArticles.headline: Citi analyst Alicia Yap tells investors in a research note that PDD‘s (PDD) Temu is likely to be the most impacted by raised tariffs and the removal of the de minimis exemption for shipments under $800. The firm, which has a Neutral rating and $150 price target on PDD shares, says that while Temu has been shifting its U.S. model to semi-managed models over the past few months, and many sellers have already front-end loaded some inventory and stored it in U.S. warehouses, the worse-than-expected
importantArticles.title: PDD’s Temu likely most impacted by raised tariffs, says Citi

importantArticles.headline: Alibaba Group Holding (NYSE:BABA) reported significant developments this past quarter, propelling its share price by 53%. Key to this upswing was the buyback of 51 million shares worth $600 million, part of a broader buyback initiative since June 2019. Positive earnings results also bolstered investor confidence, with a nearly threefold rise in net income year-over-year. Despite global market instability from new tariffs imposed by the U.S., which led to widespread declines across major...

importantArticles.headline: The global e-commerce market is projected to experience significant growth, forecasted to reach USD 73.52 trillion by 2030 from USD 25.4 trillion in 2024, marking a compound annual growth rate of 19.2%. importantArticles.headline: Alibaba Group Holding (NYSE:BABA) plans to release Qwen 3, an upgraded version of its flagship AI model, by April. China’s tech leaders have flooded the market with affordable AI services since a domestic AI startup, DeepSeek, showcased a robust model that it said cost just several million dollars to build, Bloomberg reports.
